utterances: Go ahead.
Hey, great subject today.
I like it.
I do want to - first of all, though - challenge the concept of the midlife crisis.

A buddy of mine and I have discussed this and we both bought toys but it really had not little to do with recapturing youth and everything to do with the fact that only now: A, we have no kids to carry around; and B, we can afford it.
So I bought my MX-5 Mazda.
I'd always wanted one.
It wasn't a matter of I just got to a point and said I think I'm going to go out and buy a sports car, I'd always wanted one, but only was it practical and was there enough extra in the budget.
Okay.
There you go.
I dig that.
First of all, great car, great choice.
It's an awesome car.
It's an epic sports car.
Absolutely.
You know, what's interesting…
You know, let me get your opinion on my second one.
Oh, yeah.
I have a builder actually that I'm rebuilding.
It's a '65 Corvair Corsa Turbo Convertible.
That's after they fix the rear end, isn't it?
Oh, very much so.
Yes.
This is the…
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
…trailing arm rear suspension.
And plus, even that (unintelligible) thing, that was way overstated, you know?
I don't know.
I drag the door handles on one of those.
But no, that's a fabulous builder just to bring the audience up to speed.
We're talking the Corvair with the hot engine - 1965.
This is shortly before they discontinued the car altogether.
And a terrific-looking automobile.
You're building this yourself?
Yeah.
I bought it from, actually, believe it or not, the original owner.
And it has sat for like 24 years and I had it running and driving within the weekend.
But, you know, it needs a lot.
So I've got the power train out of it right now, just cleaning it up, and refueling it, put it back in.
Well, Lynn, I would just only point out, about these two cars and the question of midlife crisis.
Both of these cars are very low.
One of the things I've noticed at the auto show is that car seats are getting higher and higher.
They have a higher - what's called an H-point where the hip in relation to the floor.
Like the BMW X6 and the Mercedes-Benz GLK and the Cadillac Provoq and the Ford Edge.
All these cars are easier to get into because, I think, you know, older people are a little stiff of joint.
And they feel more comfortable.
And our caller is obviously still very spry.
Well, not necessarily.
You've never seen me climb in and out of the Mazda yet.
But…
(Soundbite of laughter)
It does get tricky sometimes.
But boy, it's a blast to drive.
All right.
Well, thanks so much for your call.
Good hearing from you.
We're going to try and get one more quick call in here.
This is our last call because we only have a little time left.
It's Dennis(ph) from Charlotte, North Carolina.
Go ahead, Dennis.
Yes.
I recently saw on TV a Hyundai SUV that a guy had converted by putting some batteries in - all local-purchased parts.
And it would go 40 miles on one battery charge and would do up to 80 miles an hour.
Do you know anything about that product?
Well, I know that a lot of people are doing these conversions.
And it is - it's technically possible to do.
But you can't sell a product like - manufacturers can't sell a product like that in the main market because, you know, the batteries wear out too quickly.
It's too expensive.
You really don't get your investment back in fuel savings.
But five years from now, you will be able to walk into a Hyundai dealership or some other dealership and buy, technically, a car very similar to that in concept.
All right.
Well, thanks so much for your call, Dennis.
And just as a last question for you.
This is very quick, Dan.
What do you recommend to a woman who is driving a - almost 20-year-old Volvo?
I recommend the Volvo C30 - just cute as a bug, great car, very safe, just terrific.
All right.
Thanks very much.
We were talking with Dan Neil, Los Angeles Times automobile critic.
And this is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Lynn Neary.
President Bush's Supreme Court nominee Harriet Miers has endured harsh criticism for the past week, much of that from the president's fellow conservatives.
The president defended Miers this morning on NBC's ""Today"" show.
(Soundbite from ""Today"")
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: I made a decision to put somebody on the court who hadn't been a part of what they call the judicial monastery.
One man who knows something about bruising confirmation fights is Robert Bork.
He was nominated to the Supreme Court by President Reagan in 1987 and the Senate ultimately rejected him.
Judge Bork has since become a hero to many in the conservative movement.
Robert Bork joins me now to talk about Miers' nomination.

They didn't really agree much on the substance of the strike, what the strike was over, but what they did agree on was that the transit union agreed to start the process of getting the buses and subways running again while they continue to try to negotiate.
And that is the really big deal because this city has been completely paralyzed.
I mean, think about--you used to live here, Madeleine.
Think about how busy a Manhattan street is and then think about the fact that seven million people are moving underground that whole time.
So I think that the public opinion has started to sort of tilt towards annoyance and towards thinking that these folks should be getting back to work.
So was that part of the reason why the union decided to return to the bargaining table?
Well, yesterday was a really weird day, Madeleine, here in New York because on one hand, the rhetoric was reaching a fever pitch.

You had Roger Toussaint, who's the president of the Transport Workers Union Local 100, out there criticizing the state and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and anyone else who was sort of criticizing him.

But they were saying--that would be the governor, Pataki, George Pataki, and also Mayor Michael Bloomberg--was that transit workers were thugs and opportunists and were trying to bring the city to its knees.
So there was all this arguing going back and forth.

But then there was this one little story that sort of emerged, which was that this guy, Roger Toussaint, the head of the transit workers--he said, `Look, if we can just revisit this topic of pensions,' which had been a big part of the argument, `then maybe we can come back to the bargaining table.'
So pensions, that's the key sticking point?
Yeah.
And interestingly enough, it's not even the pensions of any of the current workers.
It was an issue relating to--and continues to be an issue, because it hasn't actually been solved yet--an issue relating to people that are yet to be hired.
The union loves to call them `our unborn union members.
And basically at issue was the MTA, the Metropolitan Transpiration Authority, wanted the retirement age to be moved up to 62.
The union said, `No, we want to keep it at 55.
The MTA came back and said, `OK, fine.
You can retire at 55, but you have to pay more of your salary into your pension.
And so that has been the big sticking point, and they still haven't resolved it but at least they've made enough movement that the workers are agreeing to go back to work.
So any movement on that front?
Do we know when they will return back to work?

Well, there's a little bit of a process that has to go into place now, so the sort of top brass--that would be Roger Toussaint--of the union has agreed to start the process of getting the trains and the subways--the subways and buses running.

But the thing that's still going to be a little disappointing for the average New Yorker is that we're talking eight to 12 hours before all those trains and buses are up and running and things sort of feel normal again.
NPR's Luke Burbank on the streets of New York City.
Thank you, Luke.
Sure, Madeleine.
President Trump tweeted on Thursday that young immigrants brought to this country illegally by their parents, quote, ""have nothing to worry about,"" unquote.
That message came after the Trump administration announced that they would be ending the Obama era program called Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals or DACA, unless Congress saves it by March.
But as NPR's Richard Gonzales reports, many so-called DREAMers are still worried.
When he was just a year old, Sheridan Aguirre was brought to this country from Mexico by his mother, who wanted to reunite with her husband, an agricultural worker.
She had always planned to return, but something happened.
My teachers noticed that I was doing well in school, that I was excelling.
So she decided to stay.
Aguirre graduated at the top of his high school class and then earned a degree in filmmaking from the University of Texas.
Today, he's 23 and is involved with an advocacy group lobbying for permanent legal status for the DREAMers.
Sitting in the D.C.
offices of United We Dream, Aguirre recalls how his family collectively decided to take the risk of enrolling him in DACA.
It required giving the government information, like addresses, photos, fingerprints and bank statements.
Aguirre says he believed the government's assurances that his personal information wouldn't be used against him.
They were telling me that my private information would be secure, that it would not be shared with ICE Border Patrol or any other agencies.
So I did it with confidence.
But Aguirre says that confidence was shaken by Trump's decision to end DACA.
